INTERNATIONAL UNION FOR THE CONSERVATION OF NATURE
INTERNATIONAL UNION FOR THE CONSERVATION OF NATURE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I feel that the House and the people of Canada should know that the Government of Canda appears to have instructed an Environment Canada official in Madrid to urge fellow members of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature to reject Greenpeace International's application to join this respected international organization.
Greenpeace is an internationally recognized Canadian conservation group, with operations in over 15 countries and official status at the United Nations. It is ridiculous that the Canadian Government would be so petty as to even consider opposing Greenpeace's entry into the IUCN, and it is clearly inappropriate for any Government in an organization that is comprised mostly of N.G.O's. I have already notified the Minister of the Environment (Mrs. Blais-Grenier) of my Party's objection to this, but I want the House to know that New Democrats are not alone.
November 8, 1984

I have a telegram that was sent to the President of the IUCN in which 20 of the largest non government members of the IUCN, including the World Wildlife Federation, state that the efforts by the Government of Canada to block Greenpeace's entry into the IUCN risk "opening the door to unnecessary dissension and discord that will detract from and hinder the important work that we are all committed to accomplishing under the world conservation banner".
Obviously, Environment Canada's actions in Madrid are misguided and unpopular, and I call on the Minister of the Environment to make a statement, preferably in the House, to the effect that both passive and active opposition to Greenpeace's entry into the IUCN will cease.

Mr. Speaker, three days ago the agenda of the new Government was presented to the Canadian people. However, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Turner) has criticized the Throne Speech, saying that the expectations of Canadians were not fulfilled.
Let us look at the area of federal-provincial relations.
Are Canadians disappointed that both levels of government, including Quebec, have embarked on a new path of co-operation and not confrontation? No.
Are Canadians disappointed that the federal Government has invited labour, business, and government to an economic summit to work out new strategies based on consensus? Absolutely not.
Will Canadians be disappointed that all 11 leaders in Canada will sit down to plan for our future? No.
I do not believe that the expectations of the people in my region, in my province, have been unfulfilled. In fact, they are relieved.
Perhaps the Leader of the Opposition will want to applaud this new atittude once he understands that it is absolutely necessary if we are to develop a sound future for our next generation. As an Albertan I feel confident that the concerns of my province will finally be heard and understood.

maintopic: ENTRY OF CANADIAN STEEL PRODUCTS TO UNITED STATES
ENTRY OF CANADIAN STEEL PRODUCTS TO UNITED STATES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am rising to express my extreme regret about the Government's handling of the United States Trade and Tariff Act 1984. You will be aware that as of next week legislation in the United States Congress will be passed which will adversely affect Canada's steel industry by requiring identification of Canadian pipe entering the United States.
I rise on behalf of the people of Hamilton and all those who are concerned about the steel industry, particularly in view of the Government's alleged positive relationship with the President of the United States. It seems to me that it would have been appropriate for the Minister for International Trade (Mr. Kelleher) at the very least to go to the United States directly to lobby, to ensure that Canadians would be exempted from the trade and tariff changes that will adversely affect our industry as of November 13.
In view of the new spirit of co-operation that has been developed between the Canadian and American Governments, I would suggest that the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) exercise his influence with the President of the United States with a little more than a tea party at the Rose Garden, by ensuring that the Congressional Act which will become effective on November 13 will exempt Canadian steel from the labelling provisions.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ron Stewart (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Public Works):
subtopic: GEORGIAN COLLEGE'S PROPOSAL TO ESTABLISH RESOURCE CENTRE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Minister of State for Tourism (Mr. McMillan) is aware of the proposal for a tourism-hospitality industry resource centre at Georgian College in my riding. The project will provide employment and improve the quality of tourism at a time when this important industry is facing a number of difficult challenges.
Under the former Liberal Government, Simcoe South was generally overlooked in the area of tourism. Georgian College had 800 applications for the 280 places in its tourism management program this year. Although it is the third largest co-op college in Ontario, it has, in the past, received very little federal assistance.
Georgian College's proposal is estimated to cost $3.5 million, a modest price tag for a project that will deliver over 600 training places in tourism management by 1986. The proposal has the endorsement of TIAC, Tourism Ontario, and a commitment of financial assistance from the Ontario Government. In addition, in his speech in Barrie on August 11 the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) expressed his keen interest in this project.
Georgian College offers a first rate tourism management program. The proposed resource centre will be a valuable additon to the existing program.
The new P.C. Government has recognized the importance of tourism by establishing a Ministry of State for Tourism, and by appointing a capable Minister to head it. I urge him to look seriously at this urgently needed project.

November 8, 1984

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, during the election campaign a special debate was held in Toronto on women's issues. The commitments of the Tory Party now in Government would, in hindsight, appear to be public relations window dressing, given the emptiness of the Speech from the Throne.
Canadian women deserve the respect held out to them in the Speech from the Throne, as do all Canadians. Canadian women also deserve action with programs, policies, and legislation to bring them into the mainstream of Canadian economic life.
What the women of Canada have been given by the Tory Government is a study. Some place, somewhere in this city must be a warehouse full of studies regarding women and the economy.
They are all yours.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Right, use them.
The Tory Government must act now to implement the shelter allowance program for single parents advocated by the Right Hon. Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Turner) during the election campaign. The Tory Government must act now to begin negotiations with the provinces for the implementation of a national daycare system which will provide women with greater access to jobs and training.
The Speech from the Throne has been called a motherhood speech. It is nothing but empty promises. Unfortunately for single and working mothers the Speech from the Throne is empty, and fails to recognize that in difficult economic times there is more to motherhood than being all things to all people. This Speech from the Throne is a disaster.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I wish to express the concern of my constituents and my Party and also of 300,000 members of the Public Service about rumours and leaks according to which 15,000 Public Service jobs are to disappear tonight, as part of Mr. Wilson's statement. These rumours seem to be part of a deliberate campaign aimed at getting the public to anticipate changes that will cost jobs instead of creating them.

People voted for change in my riding of Ottawa Centre and across Canada, but in my opinion very few voted to make the Public Service a scapegoat in order to appease the business
community. There are real challenges for the Public Service to be met, but under the Liberal Government the Public Service was overmanaged, and its morale suffered from repeated six and five freezes and other such steps. I would not like to see the same thing continued under the new Government.
To give an example, the new Government has let 200 contract employees in Canada Employment and Immigration go, despite the fact that unemployment is at record levels and that jobs counsellors in CEIC cannot do the job adequately now because there are too few of them.
As Leader of the Progressive Conservative Party, the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) promised during the election campaign that, while the Government supported a need for restraint in government spending, "we are not in favour of this goal being achieved on the backs of public servants". I call upon the Government to live up to this commitment and not make public employees sacrificial victims in its budgetary policy.

Mr. Speaker, sloth and wastefulness, arrogance and corruption, these were the characteristics of a Liberal-Socialist alliance too long in power. Their pigeons came home to roost on September 4. On the other hand, sound financial management and prudence in the handling of the public purse will be the hallmarks of the new Government.
Since September 17 the Cabinet, and in particular the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson), have been diligently working on an economic statement which will show the true state of Canada's national finances and will set us on the road to economic recovery. Controlling the deficit, that legacy of the Trudeau years which hangs around the necks of Canadians like a stone, will have to be uppermost in the mind of the Minister.
I urge all parliamentarians and all Canadians to listen carefully this evening at 6.30 when the Minister of Finance will pull the switch, thereby putting Canada back on the track toward a bright and prosperous future.

subsubtopic: SUGGESTED TOPIC FOR NATIONAL ECONOMIC SUMMIT AGENDA
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Right Hon. Prime Minister. It was inconceivable to those of us on this side of the House that there was no mention of post-secondary education in the Throne Speech. On behalf of the students of the University of British Columbia and other universities across the country, does the Prime Minister intend to make it his personal priority when he meets the Premiers at the upcoming summit to place post-secondary education on the agenda? If so, would he consult the students of the country so that they may help set the agenda for the national economic summit?

subsubtopic: SUGGESTED TOPIC FOR NATIONAL ECONOMIC SUMMIT AGENDA
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, indeed it is our intention to discuss it with the Premiers next week. This is one of the reasons why it was not mentioned in any specifics a little earlier this week. Notwithstanding the observation yesterday of the Right Hon. Leader of the Opposition that he thought we were indulging in perhaps too much consultation, I would be delighted to take his suggestion and consult further with the students.

subsubtopic: SUGGESTED TOPIC FOR NATIONAL ECONOMIC SUMMIT AGENDA
speechtext: Hear, hear!

subsubtopic: SUGGESTED TOPIC FOR NATIONAL ECONOMIC SUMMIT AGENDA
speechtext: I am sure the university students of the country would welcome any opportunity to give the right hon. gentleman some advice.

speechtext:

the House whether he would favour attaching some conditions or setting some sort of guidelines so that we in the House can be assured that money of the taxpayers of Canada destined to post-secondary education is used by the provinces of Canada for the purpose of education?

subtopic: USE OF TAX MONEY BY PROVINCES
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I think the manner in which the question is set out indicates the fundamental difference between our two Parties. The Right Hon. Leader of the Opposition appears to presuppose that if we make an agreement with the provinces they will do something improper. subtopic: USE OF TAX MONEY BY PROVINCES
speechtext: Before meeting the Premiers, I think the right hon. gentleman ought to look at the facts to see how that money is actually being spent by the provinces.

speakeroldname: Right Hon. John N. Turner (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, could the Right Hon. Prime Minister inform the House and students across the country whether he is in favour of setting national objectives, with the agreement of the provinces, in the field of post-secondary education?

The Leader of the Opposition is right in bringing up an issue that is absolutely vital, and on which I would say an unprecedented amount of consultation and co-operation will be necessary. In fact, this has been the position taken by the Leader of the Opposition, and rightly so, throughout his public life, and I can assure him that it will be ours as well, especially in an area as vitally important as this one.
Starting next Tuesday, we shall be consulting not only on the principle but also on implementation procedures.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of State for Youth. However, with your indulgence and, through you, I should like to offer my congratulations to the Minister on her appointment to such a sensitive post at this time of crisis for our youth.

speakeroldname: Right Hon. John N. Turner (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in approaching the Premiers, in discussing the question of post-secondary education, and in negotiating agreements with them next March, would the Prime Minister tell
Will the Minister enlighten this House and the youth of Canada on the areas of her responsibilities with respect to legislative procedure and programs, as well as the criteria for the allocation of grants? For example, will she comment on her

November 8, 1984
Oral Questions
input to the decision which cut direct job training for youth to a mere $27 million, as announced by her colleague, the Minister of Employment and Immigration?
[ Translation]

Mr. Speaker, first I would like to thank my hon. colleague for her words of congratulations. I think that in the coming months, she will be able to appreciate what I intend to accomplish in the Department for which the Right Hon. Prime Minister has made me responsible.
As for the Hon. Member's question about future legislation, I may remind her that, through no fault of my own, I am the third Minister in seven months to head this Department. With my departmental officials, we are first trying to clean house. We shall be consulting young people themselves, but not through studies of statistics and statistics on studies, of which we have had more than enough from my predecessors.
Hear, hear!

As for the grant funding to which you referred, we will know after this evening. It is not for me to say now what amounts will be allocated for youth.

Finally, the Hon. Member referred to the announcement made by the Minister of Employment and Immigration. This is not my responsibility right now, even though we have conferred. This is a pilot project. I will be delighted to work along with her to develop new ones.
Hear, hear!

Mr. Speaker, I am very disappointed that, while cleaning house, she had to cut out one-third of the budget for our youth. However, the question was not related to the dollars in the grant. It was related to criteria. Perhaps we can come back to that.
In particular, I am concerned about an interview which the Minister had with Mr. Bernard Descoteaux of Le Devoir, in which she stated:
[ Translation]
She would like to suggest that people look at the 85 per cent who are doing well.

I am really concerned that young people in difficulty, les decrocheurs, have to turn elsewhere. Will young Canadians have to turn to these other 85 per cent, according to our Minister, for help, or will they get some help, those who are in need, those who are contemplating suicide, and those who have not done well, drop-outs, and students? Are they going to turn elsewhere or to you, Mrs. Minister?

Mr. Speaker, perhaps I may point out that at the time of the interview, 85 per cent of young Canadians were able to function normally, despite difficult economic conditions. I also said, if I am being quoted correctly, that of course we were going to take care of people in difficulty. I feel, however, that it is also up to young Canadians and I am thinking of those who are able to function with everybody's help to do their share. In this Government, Mr. Speaker, everyone will have to do his share, and that includes Canada's youth.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Right Hon. Prime Minister.
During the election campaign, the Prime Minister promised that his Government would make changes in the Liberals' policies. More specifically, he promised Canadian women a number of policies on economic equality. He said that Canadian corporations seeking federal government contracts would have to provide affirmative action programs and equal pay for work of equal value. In the Throne Speech, the Government made a complete turnabout. Why?

I think my hon. friend, the Leader of the New Democratic Party, is mistaken. In fact, there was a great deal in the Throne Speech about the status of women in Canada, including the particular issue he is raising. I can say that at this very moment, we have programs that are being quickly examined by Cabinet and my office so as not to delay implementation of the principle in question.

Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister is giving the House the same old answers that we used to hear from the Liberal Government when he sat on this side of the House. When the Prime Minister made the promise during the election campaign-
Oh, oh!
Well, we don't want to bring back the other people who used to break their promises, to go back on that side. One is as bad as the other. They are a little sensitive, these guys to my right.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext:
Order, please. The Hon. Member for Oshawa on a supplementary question.

November 8, 1984
Another 30 years in opposition will do you a lot of good, fellows.
Hear, hear!
You should know, Ed.

Just look at Nova Scotia.
The Prime Minister knows what is in the Throne Speech. He also knows that there is no commitment to implement these specific promises he made. He promised Canadian women concrete action, that as Prime Minister he would insist that all companies doing business with the Government have programs such as affirmative action, equal pay for work of equal value, in place. Why is he not now giving that to the people of Canada, the women, instead of studying it again for the future?
Mr. Speaker, when I see the spectacle that is going on in front of me, I should remind all of the people over there that one thing the Canadian people cannot stand is a lovers' quarrel in public.
Hear, hear!

You have got along all these years; don't spoil it now.
Our commitment, the pursuit of equality for women, is at the top of our legislative and governmental priorities. I can assure the Hon. Member that we shall be acting on many fronts to satisfy the very legitimate request of all Canadian women that fairness and equality of opportunity be theirs.
Hear, hear!

Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister has spent most of the period since September 4 reading the former Prime Minister's answers to questions. I warn him, because he saw what happened to the guy on my right, and to his predecessor, that he will not be around for nearly the same period of time unless he changes his approach.
I want to ask the Prime Minister this question because he is both Prime Minister and a lawyer of considerable reputation. He knows that Section 19 of the Human Rights Act will permit the Government of Canada, without making a study and without bringing legislation before the House, actually to implement the promises made in regard to equality for women. If he believes, as he said in the NAC debate, as he said in British Columbia, and as he said in Toronto during the summer of 1984, that his Government will act on equality, why does he not use the Human Rights Act, consider the unequal state in which Canadian women have been living for decades, and implement now the promises he made? We do not need more studies.
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, in fairness I think the Hon. Member would acknowledge that the House has only been in session for some three days and that there will be an economic statement tonight which, of necessity, requires priority treatment. The priority we plan to give to equality in the status of women in a number of important areas is, I can assure the Hon. Member, at the top of our list, and there shall be effective action in those areas.

subtopic: PRESENCE IN GALLERY OF PRIME MINISTER OF FRANCE

speechtext:
Given the very special relationship that exists between our countries-

subtopic: PRESENCE IN GALLERY OF PRIME MINISTER OF FRANCE
speechtext: Hear, hear!

speechtext: Before calling the Hon. Member for Eglinton-Lawrence, may I remind the House that the purpose of Question Period is short answers and short questions.

Mr. Speaker, my question is addressed to the Hon. Secretary of State. First, I would like to congratulate him not only on his re-election but on his appointment to his important portfolio.
The Minister well knows that for years one of the ongoing concerns of the previous Government, and of all students and all members of faculties of institutions across the country, has been that funds transferred by the Government of Canada to the provinces for post-secondary education might have been partially, or even largely, diverted to other areas and purposes. Does the Secretary of State intend to implement the law which requires him to determine what each province actually spends in the area of post-secondary education, and report this to the House? Does the Secretary of State intend to ferret out the truth and find out where the provinces are actually spending the money given them by the federal Government which was intended to be devoted exclusively to the benefit of postsecondary education?

November 8, 1984
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, I would like to acknowledge the good wishes of the Hon. Member and in turn offer my congratulations to him.
The Hon. Member will recall that it was the amendment put forward by the Hon. Minister of Employment and Immigration during debate on Bill C-12 dealing with post-secondary funding which called for the responsible action in reporting of which the Hon. Member speaks.
The Minister, by pointing out this fact, which I would have wanted to have mentioned if there were time-
Oh, oh!

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: No. The Hon. Member knows full well that his opportunity now is to place a supplementary question.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is in fact addressed to the Right Hon. Prime Minister. I am sure he has been listening well to the very point the Secretary of State just mentioned. How does the Prime Minister square the views of the Secretary of State with his own when, in Chicoutimi, Quebec, in the heat of the election campaign, he said that he found repugnant the provisions of this amendment which was in fact moved by his own Minister of Employment and Immigration? He said that he found this amendment repugnant in that it required the provinces to be brought to give an account of how they spend federal funds earmarked for higher education. [Translation]
"It is a dimension of the Act which I find repugnant-"

The Prime Minister said that he wanted it changed.
Mr. Speaker, it was the attitude of the former Government that I found repugnant. That was made very clear.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Employment and Immigration and relates to one of the few employment projects that she has announced to date, the Canada Works Program. I would like to know why the Minister is following the Liberal practice of denying funding to women's crisis centres under the Canada Works Program? That is a program which is very necessary for many people right across the country, and the Minister's program and guidelines specifically disallow funding to women's crisis centres.

speakeroldname: Hon. Flora MacDonald (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the Hon. Member knows when he refers to the Canada Works Program which I announced that it will indeed create some 70,000 new jobs and many of those jobs, I trust, will be allocated to women, as I have encouraged all Members of Parliament to see to it. This is so that women will indeed receive a larger number of jobs than they did last year under the program as it was being managed at that time. I would urge the Hon. Member to put forward good and viable proposals which will all be considered.

Mr. Speaker, I presume that the Minister is now reversing her regulations and guidelines and is now saying to us that crisis centres will be eligible for funding. Is that what she is saying to us? If she is not saying that to us, could she be very specific in explaining why those groups will not be eligible for funding?

speakeroldname: Hon. Flora MacDonald (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the Hon. Member will know that I again instituted the establishment of constituency advisory boards in order to bring to the attention of Members and of the Minister those projects which should be funded. I would urge the Hon. Member to attend to his constituency advisory board, to appoint one if he has not yet done so, and to ask it to bring forward its recommendations.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Regional Industrial Expansion. First let me congratulate the Minister on his appointment and wish him well in his deliberations.
As the Minister knows, a fire destroyed the Number 26 colliery in Glace Bay in April, 1984, taking the life of one man and displacing 1,200 workers. Recently the regional Minister for Nova Scotia announced that that coal mine would be sealed and that certain moneys would be allocated for the development of another coal mine. Unfortunately, that Minister did not make known in his announcement its dollar value, the number of jobs that would be created by the coal mine, or the duration of those jobs. Is the Minister prepared to provide the details of that announcement? Furthermore, is he prepared to give a firm commitment to a new coal development in the Town of Glace Bay?
Hon. Sinclair Stevens (Minister of Regional Industrial
Expansion): Mr. Speaker, I thank the Hon. Member for his question. I would indicate that we too are most concerned about the situation to which he refers. As far as the IB expenditure is concerned, the Hon. Member will be pleased to
November 8, 1984

learn that we have agreed to the employment of over a hundred people for 10 weeks to go ahead with the clean-up operation that is necessary in the IB situation. That is in anticipation of taking a fresh look at the feasibility of opening IB itself. As far as the total amount to be expended is concerned, I was speaking with Joseph Shannon this morning and he is still unable to identify the exact amount, but I can assure the Hon. Member that I will provide that detail when it is available.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is directed to the same Minister. Although we have not got a very strong commitment from the Minister, I would point out to him that in the briefs submitted by the Mayor of Glace Bay and the President of the United Mine Workers of America, a number of factors were raised, with all of which I agree. However, there was one glaring omission, a pre-retirement package for older miners at the Cape Breton Development Corporation.
Would the Minister issue a directive, pursuant to Section 99 of the new Financial Administration Act, suggesting that the Corporation President enter into negotiations with the UMW and/or invoke the provisions of the Labour Adjustment Program, thereby enabling miners who are 55 years of age and older to avail themselves of a pre-retirement plan, thus creating new jobs for younger Canadians in that area?

speakeroldname: Hon. Sinclair Stevens (Minister of Regional Industrial Expansion):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, in reply to the Hon. Member, who has referred to my meeting with Jake Campbell and His Worship, the Mayor of Glace Bay, I am sure he will be very pleased to learn that Jake Campbell has sent a telex to me, as a result of this Government's fast action, to say that the people of Glace Bay smile once again.
Hear, hear!

Oral Questions
will be provided from both the federal and provincial Governments?

Mr. Speaker, in regard to the comment of the Hon. Member about students, I do not think that I could improve by an adjective on a statement in regard to that important element of our society which was made by the Hon. Leader of the Opposition during the leadership campaign when he said to students, "Your generation is going to be strangled if Ottawa continues to go into debt at the current pace". He made that statement on April 3 of last year. I agree with that statement. Students require economic growth, and economic growth requires dealing with a Government's expenditures which are out of control, and dealing with the deficit, to create co-operation with the provinces and the private sector, and to create a climate which will allow for the creation of jobs so that our young people can go back to work.

Mr. Speaker, I gather that the Prime Minister believes that it is more advantageous for students to go into debt than it is for the Government to go into slight debt in order to ensure not only that there will be educational opportunity but also the prospect of real economic growth.

Mr. Speaker, I will pursue my supplementary question to the Prime Minister along these lines. Will the Government consider a new post-secondary education act, as proposed by the Canadian Association of University Teachers, which is supported by the Canadian Federation of Students, to provide the following: one, a national tripartite, independent post-secondary education advisory council involving the federal and provincial Governments and the post-secondary education community; two, a House of Commons standing committee on science, research and post-secondary education to provide a periodic review of government initiatives in regard to post-secondary initiatives; and, three-

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: Order, please. Mr. Speaker, I thought that the suggestions made by my hon. friend were worthy of active consideration. Pursuant to meetings which began this morning between the Secretary of State in regard to post-secondary education, I thank him for those suggestions and the Government will take them into active consideration.

Oral Questions AUDITOR GENERAL

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the President of the Treasury Board and is in connection with a lawsuit being brought by the Auditor General against Petro-Canada and Petrofina. With respect to that transaction the President of the Treasury Board will know that we are paying the lawyers for the Auditor General through one budget, we are paying the judges through another budget, and we are paying for the defalcations of Petro-Canada in one way or another, which is all costing the taxpayers a lot of money. I would ask the President of the Treasury Board if he would step in to ensure that interdepartmental rivalries get cleaned up in a hurry so that they will not cost the country a lot of money for this nonsense?

speakeroldname: Hon. Robert de Cotret (President of the Treasury Board):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I would like to tell the Hon. Member that I am well aware of the case.
You are lucky to have him.
Sure, we are lucky to have all of our colleagues here with us.
We are nicer to you than they are.

Ask questions. I have been waiting for them.
The question is one of which I am well aware. There is a suit which has been brought by the Auditor General, and I have had a number of discussions with him. We want the courts to decide on that matter, and we are following it very closely.

After campaigning so actively with all Members opposite on a program that would allow the Auditor General to be given complete access to the ways in which all taxpayers' money is being spent, including Crown corporations, how can the Government now claim that this is a matter which it should study, when it promised the Canadian people that the Auditor General would be given access to all such corporations?

Wait until I have answered the question. Then you can howl, yowl, jowl and do what you like.

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development. I will begin by congratulating him on being named to a post which is among the most interesting and challenging of any portfolio in government.

speechtext:

Member for Yukon-to get this mine back into production. Member's question, let me say, Mr. Speaker, it is true, as he indicated, that I met on October 24 with a number of people in Faro in order to deal with the question of the closing of the mine. subtopic: SPORTS POOL AND LOTO CANADA WINDING-UP ACT MEASURE TO ESTABLISH

speechtext: The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Epp (Provencher) that Bill C-2, an Act respecting the winding-up of the Canada Sports Pool Corporation and Loto Canada Incorporated, be read the second time and referred to the Standing Committee on Health, Welfare and Social Affairs.

subtopic: SPORTS POOL AND LOTO CANADA WINDING-UP ACT MEASURE TO ESTABLISH
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise to support this Bill for the winding up of the Canada Sports Pool Corporation and the Loto Canada Corporation.
In the debate which we had in this Chamber earlier this morning the Minister of National Health and Welfare (Mr. Epp) set out succinctly and persuasively the reasons which justify this Bill at this time. We also heard from the Hon. Member for York West (Mr. Marchi) who had the thankless task of trying to outline, on behalf of the Liberal Party, some of the concerns which they have about it. We heard as well from the Hon. Member for Thunder Bay-Nipigon (Mr. Epp). In a moment or two I would like to join debate arising out of those comments, particularly the comments of the Member for York West.
The speech of the Minister drew the attention of the House to the fact that this legislation, apart from winding up the sports pool and the lottery corporation, is symbolic in two senses. First, it conveys very clearly the intention of the Government to have a co-operative working relationship with the provinces. That is why the Minister of State for Fitness and Amateur Sport (Mr. Jelinek) is now negotiating with the provinces to work out the continuing arrangements for lotteries at the provincial level. Second, the Minister also said that this symbolizes the intent of our new Government to get out of the lottery business. It is for that reason, Mr. Speaker, that I speak to this Bill.
There is nothing which could give me greater satisfaction than rising to speak my first words in this very special Chamber in support of a measure that will not only be doing away with part of the old order, but also symbolically will be saying to Canadians from coast to coast-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
subtopic: SPORTS POOL AND LOTO CANADA WINDING-UP ACT MEASURE TO ESTABLISH
speechtext: Order, please.

subtopic: SPORTS POOL AND LOTO CANADA WINDING-UP ACT MEASURE TO ESTABLISH
speechtext:
It will be conveying a message to Canadians from coast to coast that the Government has more and better things to do than to be fostering gambling.

Mr. Speaker, I deeply regret that the governments of our country, at the federal and, especially, at the provincial level, ever started these lotteries. In my opinion, state lotteries are not a true function of the public administration of this country. Today, we are unfortunately blest with this culture, attitude or
Sports Pool Corporation
practice because of state lotteries that tell Canadians they have a chance to win. That is the unfortunate state of affairs we have today.
I realize it is not easy to go back to what the situation was in Canada before governments got involved in lotteries. However, we must start somewhere, and that is why I am supporting this bill.

Mr. Speaker, lotteries sponsored by governments give Canadians false hopes. They are built upon a message of false dreams. They have created an appetite for gambling where none existed before.
In 1970 I worked at Queen's Park as the executive assistant to the Attorney General of that province. At that time we received submissions from people who wanted to start large scale, province-wide lotteries in Ontario. One of the arguments advanced in support of such province-wide lotteries was that annually $4.5 million to $5 million was going out of the Province of Ontario to buy Irish Sweepstake tickets. The great argument was that if we had our own lottery in the Province of Ontario the $5 million would stay in the province and would be a marvellous thing for the balance of payments.
At that time, and correctly in my view, the Government of Ontario rejected that notion. The lotteries permitted in the province were only those at the local level to support service clubs and sports teams, and so on, trying to raise a little money for an immediate and clearly identified local purpose. Times changed, and in the development of this lottery culture that we now have around us on all fronts in Canada, even the Government of Ontario succumbed. Today that $4.5 million to $5 million, which was the concern in those times, is but the advertising budget for the Ontario Lottery Corporation for several months. The provincial Government of Ontario has joined, as have provincial governments across the country, in an act of delusion, and in the creation of false hopes. In many respects it is something like the practice in Roman times of giving bread and circuses to the people to distract them from other things which the government might more properly be doing, or found it could not do.
In fact, the insidious new attitude has permeated so deeply, Mr. Speaker, that when people now begin a project at the local level for community benefit the first question is almost always, "Where do we apply for a Wintario grant?". They no longer wonder how they can be self-reliant, stand on their own feet and do these things in and of themselves. Instead they wonder how they can get a little more money out of the Government through this special fund. Indeed, it is inimical to the patterns of public finance in this country that funds should be so raised and kept in a segregated fund for purposes that are unrelated to the general priorities of government, all of which must come out of the consolidated Revenue Fund.
The Hon. Member for York West, in speaking to this Bill this morning, referred to lotteries as "noble". I find them to be absolutely undermining the traditional values that have built

November 8, 1984
Sports Pool Corporation
this country. The Hon. Member asked the House where the money would come from if the Government suspends the operations of the Sports Pool Corporation. As Hon. Members know, there is no money currently coming in through this device. Indeed, it is losing money. It is the taxpayers of Canada who are currently footing the bill.
I submit that it is rather typical of the economic fiscal thinking of the Party opposite, on whose behalf the Member for York West was speaking, that that kind of deficit approach to financing is one that he would still want to see maintained. It is similar to a compulsive gambler who just keeps on hoping.
The Hon. Member also talked about the national mandate given our Government. He asked how the national purpose and national will was being fulfilled in Canada at this time by cancelling something like the sports pool and the Loto Canada Corporation. Our mandate as a new Conservative Government is to foster those values and to see a restoration in this country of those values that have built this country and made it strong. I submit that the state-supported lotteries are just the opposite of that.
I think of a statement made last year by a new Canadian of Italian background in Toronto who had just won a substantial amount of money in a lottery. He stated that he knew before coming to Canada that it was the land of hope and promise. It was the land where new Canadians could come and find a great new life. We have always believed that about Canada and indeed about the new world. However, traditionally the way of building a new life on the North American continent came from hard work, the opportunities which this rich land affords, and from a little bit of luck that is inherent in life. To think now that one has achieved the promise of the new world by winning a big cash prize in a lottery tells us how far and devastating this attitude has become in our country, where we turn to the wheel of fortune, rather than put our shoulder to the wheel, to make this country work.
We also heard this morning from the Hon. Member for Thunder Bay-Nipigon who spoke on behalf of the New Democratic Party. I can say with confidence that his position and mine are virtually identical. He said that we are dealing with something which is a moral and social issue. He referred to speeches made in this Chamber by members of his Party and members of our Party over the years who have taken exception to the practice of governments getting into the gambling business.
Gambling is not an appropriate way to raise government revenues. It is regressive in nature because, as the Hon. Member pointed out, studies have indicated that it is the poor who buy lottery tickets. In my view it is a sham for people to say that it should simply be treated as a voluntary tax. It is government advertising that has created this demand where no demand existed before.
We now have an opportunity to send a very clear message to the country that a new day has arrived in Ottawa. When we talk about peace, order and good government as being the cornerstones of our Constitution, we truly mean good government. We know that there are some things that the Government can, must and should do, and others which the Government should never do, no matter how much could be raised for the public coffers. Just because lotteries raise money is no reason that the Government should be into the act.
Indeed, to this very day the Criminal Code of Canada contains provisions that make gambling illegal. That law used to apply to all Canadians. Governments then decided to get into the gambling business and introduced special legislation to legitimize that which had been illegal according to the traditions and the values of this country. Not only were special laws created for the Government, but at the same time that the Government promoted gambling through the state-run lotteries, the law officers of the Crown continued to prosecute other Canadians for gambling according to those offences that were still in the Criminal Code. That is the kind of double standard that is unacceptable in this country and it understandably gives rise to an attitude of cynicism on the part of citizens of this country.
As a result of striking down that kind of provision today, we are taking a step in the right direction to get this country back on the right track. That, too, is why I support this Bill. Winding up lotteries in any way possible, on every front possible, is desirable and in the public interest.
This being 1984, we cannot close this debate without noting, as the Hon. Member for Thunder Bay-Nipigon would have done had he not exhausted his time, a relevant Orwellian passage. He pointed out that Orwell wrote in his novel Nineteen Eighty-Four.
The Lottery, with its weekly pay-out of enormous prizes, was the one public event to which the proles paid serious attention. It was probable that there were some millions of proles for whom the Lottery was the principal if not the only reason for remaining alive.
We know that what Orwell was trying to describe in his novel was life under the oppressive state. It was the state that knew better than its citizens how everything should and could be done. Although we have reached calendar year 1984, fortunately we have not reached the Orwellian 1984.
This Bill, short as it may be, speaks eloquently of our determination to turn back that tide. This is but a beginning, because the provinces are still in this game to an unacceptable degree. However, we are turning back that tide and we must continue in the House and elsewhere in the country to champion any measure which will restore a proper sense of the role of government.
I support the Bill before the House that will wind up the Canadian Sports Pool Corporation and the Loto Canada Corporation.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise with pleasure to take part in this debate involving the winding down of the Canadian sports pool and part of the gambling business in Canada.
I congratulate the Government for taking the initiative to make certain that the second piece of legislation debated in this Parliament would be one which takes care of the gambling issue on the federal scene. Also I congratulate the Hon. Member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore (Mr. Boyer) on the speech which he just made and his ringing defence of the natural position of the work ethic, competitive spirit and the role of the market-place, invoking those principles for which Canadians have hungered for entire generations. I am glad he planted his flag very firmly. These are the principles which we intend to enunciate throughout the next four years. Canadians will appreciate it as health returns to the economy as a result of this particular emphasis.
I should like to point out at the outset that the path taken by the previous Government in instituting the sports pool was not the normal way in which it operated. It began a new company. In previous years that Government would normally take over a thriving industry and run it into the ground. It was the old story of how one started a small business in Canada-one bought a big one and let the government do its work and it would become a small one. Normally the Liberal Government would not have started a new business as it did on that occasion. It started a new corporation and in this case the market-place dictated what ought to happen to it in the first place. It died a natural death financially, it died a natural death. I wish it would have followed its normal pattern and taken over the gambling industry in places like Atlantic City and Vegas. If it had done so, Atlantic City and Vegas would be out of business by now. As the saying goes, if it were to nationalize the Sahara desert, it would run out of sand. It broke its normal pattern, but I am glad to say that the law of

November 8, 1984
Sports Pool Corporation
supply and demand has done its work on this particular corporation.
It is sad to say that the losses this corporation experienced are reason enough to wind it down. These losses tend to overshadow the real reason for doing so. When the corporation can lose $46 million in a few months and require another $16 million or $18 million to wind down and satisfy all existing contracts, it ought to die. People might be led to believe that this is the only reason we are shutting it down. However, the real reason we are shutting it down is because it is wrong.

subtopic: SPORTS POOL AND LOTO CANADA WINDING-UP ACT MEASURE TO ESTABLISH
speechtext: You do not believe in gambling.

subtopic: SPORTS POOL AND LOTO CANADA WINDING-UP ACT MEASURE TO ESTABLISH
speechtext:
That is right, except at election time, except when Tories run. Then it is not a gamble. It is a sure thing and there is nothing wrong with it.
It is wrong for the Government to engage in this kind of business. There are two, three or perhaps more specific reasons, but I want to deal with at least two of them. The first reason is because of what it does to our people, the debilitating effect on people. It might be worth noting that becoming involved in the gambling business on the part of any government is a good symptom that something is wrong with the economy. We should take a look around the world at what countries institute a gambling business on behalf of the government. We will find that almost, if not entirely without exception, they are countries with failing economies.

speechtext: They are all in the gambling business.

subtopic: SPORTS POOL AND LOTO CANADA WINDING-UP ACT MEASURE TO ESTABLISH
speechtext:
They are in the gambling business. I think it ought to be wound down, but if the Hon. Member wants to look at a real example, he should take a look at Mexico where people walk the streets with boards, two feet by four feet, with rows of lottery tickets and on which they flash the results of lotteries. In that country lottery is a big business. If the Hon. Member thinks that lotteries in Alberta, British Columbia and Ontario are a big business, he should go to Mexico where there is no unemployment insurance and a high unemployment rate. He will see what the lottery business has done to that country. As bad as the lottery business on the provincial scene is, it is nothing compared with what it is in some underdeveloped countries. I hope the Hon. Member will agree with me. Therefore, it is wrong because of what it does to our people. First, it creates a world of illusion. Somehow it creates a dream in the minds of the people engaged in it that they can get wealthy suddenly, that overnight they can solve all of their financial problems.
It is almost impossible for that to happen. If you look at the odds of gambling, it is almost impossible for people to succeed. For them to be given the dream that overnight they will be wealthy is a cruel hoax. In fact, the odds are written in such a way as to make sure they do not succeed. It is impossible for
them. Therefore, the world of illusion is a cruel hoax that we play on them.
The second related reason it is wrong is that it gives people the impression that sudden wealth is great, that it is healthy, that it will be a solution to their problems. That does not happen. There are very few people who can handle sudden wealth.

subtopic: SPORTS POOL AND LOTO CANADA WINDING-UP ACT MEASURE TO ESTABLISH
speechtext: I would sure like to try it.

subtopic: SPORTS POOL AND LOTO CANADA WINDING-UP ACT MEASURE TO ESTABLISH
speechtext:
I would not mind trying. I would take the risk. However, the fact is it does not happen very often that people can handle it. If you look at the record of those who have become suddenly wealthy after winning a lottery, it is not a very good history of what that industry has done to people. People just cannot handle that kind of sudden wealth. As my friend, the Hon. Member for Western Arctic (Mr. Nickerson) says, we would like to give it a chance, but usually it does not work.
The ads shown on television, the million dollar lottery ads, show people who have just won a million. They are on their yacht. They will be getting their Rolls Royce. They have all the luxurious amenities of life. It makes it look as though that were the solution to everything. That is a cruel hoax that we play on people. It is just a terrible illusion that we have.
Second, as my friend, the Hon. Member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore mentioned, it is a tax on the poor. Studies have shown that it is people mostly in the lower income groups and lower educational brackets who buy those tickets. It is ironic that you do not find lottery vending machines or tables next to the savings deposit wicket of the banks. Is it not strange that when people go to the bank or credit union they do not find lottery tickets being sold there? There you would have the choice between saving your money in a reasonably safe place or gambling it and being a pretty sure loser.
They do not put them there. Where do they put them? They put them in the grocery stores, in the convenience stores and out on the street where you cannot miss them. They make sure that impulse buying becomes the biggest trap for the people who can be trapped into buying lottery tickets. Next to the potato chips is where you find the lottery tickets. Next to the milk bar you will find the lottery tickets. Given a choice between what they need and what they like, they will buy what they like. That is too bad. It becomes a tax on the poor, and that is wrong.
The third reason why it is wrong is that it is wrong for a government to create the business which eventually makes most people losers. I would have thought that a government would see its mandate and its mission to make people winners, to make people successful, to make people feel good and do well. As soon as a government institutes a lottery industry, it makes sure that most people are going to lose. If not, the lottery business is not going to win. It is not going to work. The only reason they can give a million dollar prize is that there have been a million people giving a dollar who are not going to get it. Knock off the cost of advertising, promotion and sales, and it will take two million sales to give a million dollar bonus.

Most people have to lose. It is morally wrong for a government to start a business which will make most people losers and trick the unsuspecting people into thinking that they are going to win.
Finally, and I again echo my friend from Etobicoke-Lake-shore, it is morally wrong for a government to encourage an economy, a life or a lifestyle simply of chance. Chance is just what the word says. It is risk over which you have absolutely no control. It is wrong for a government to do that. Our country was built well and built strong, not because of lotteries, but because of hard work, not because of lotteries or chance in the gambling sense, but because of the investment of hard work, initiative and chance in the competitive sense, not in the numbers game. It is morally wrong for a government to get involved in a business that depends on chance for success.
I compliment the Government and the Minister for taking the initiative to wind this corporation down, getting out of the business, not simply because we are losing money, although that is reason enough, but to undo the record of the previous Government and start establishing those principles upon which we will rebuild this nation in order to make sure that our people will find satisfying, productive, creative lives and find fulfilment in what they have accomplished instead of some shallow sense of fulfilment from what they have won.

Perhaps I should reiterate what, in fact, is stated in the Bill and why this Government finally took the only honourable step
November 8, 1984

to wind down the Canadian Sports Pool Corporation. It was done for numerous reasons. The first and main reason, of course, is the fact that there was a 1979 agreement with the provinces giving the provinces the jurisdiction for gaming operations. I did not hear any reference from the Hon. Member in that regard. In order to establish a spirit of co-operation between the federal Government and the provinces-rather than the spirit of confrontation which has existed over the past decade or more fostered by the previous Liberal administration-we took the step of closing down the sports pool and are now in the process of legislating that decision in order to create harmony between this Government and the provinces.
Second, of course, because the sports pool was such a well run operation-typical of the Liberal administration-it was losing over $1 million a week, which made the decision that much easier.
There were some individuals who suggested to us that we not close down the sports pool but improve upon it, make it more comprehensive and simple and then use it as a tool to try to get money out of the provinces in order to close it down. We rejected that option because that is exactly the way the previous Government operated. It used to have a big stick in order to deal with the provinces. That sort of federal-provincial relationship is out of the window as of September 4 last, I can assure you of that.
My main purpose in participating in this debate today, Mr. Speaker, is once again to assure Canadians of this Government's commitment to contributions for the Calgary Games of $200 million despite the closure of the sports pool. As I stated at a press conference on September 21, and I quote:
This Government unconditionally accepts the commitment to provide financial support for the 1988 Olympics in Calgary to a total of $200 million.
I will expound in a few moments, Mr. Speaker, as to our commitment and where we intend to raise the money for that commitment. However, I would like to take a few comments to follow up on some of the historical background of the sports pool and lotteries in general, following on the statements made earlier today by my colleague, the Minister of National Health and Welfare (Mr. Epp). As you may know, Mr. Speaker, the first lottery initiated goes back to 1973, which was the Olympic lottery. This was initiated by the Liberal Government at that time for the purpose of trying to raise funds for the Montreal Olympics, which were held three years later in 1976. There were problems immediately and the Conservative Party, in Opposition at that time, made those problems known to the House and to the Canadian people. We suggested that the Government should not get itself involved in the lottery business at that time. However, being in the position we were as Opposition, we did not get very far.
It is somewhat ironic that in those days I happened to be the critic for fitness and amateur sports, for the Olympics and for lotteries. It was under those conditions that on February 27, 1976, and again on March 29 of the same year, I brought numerous and specific facts to the attention of the House regarding irregularities concerning advertising and ticket sales
Sports Pool Corporation
with which the lottery was fraught. Specifically, on June 1, 1976, I went on to call for an investigation into the Olympic lottery. However, in spite of numerous concerns outlined not only in this House but across the country, Loto Canada followed the Olympic lottery and was established just after those horrendous problems which developed in the Olympic lottery on June 7, 1976.
We continued, Mr. Speaker, to try to clean up the operation because we were promised by the Government in power at that time that the lottery would continue only as long as it took to pay for the overrun of the Montreal games. It is for that reason, and that reason only, that we eventually supported the formation of that lottery on a temporary basis, with the understanding that it would be closed down after the overrun of the 1976 Olympics was paid for. That was not to be the case, unfortunately, and, as you know, Mr. Speaker, the Government went on to create other lotteries, and so we found ourselves in the situation in which we are today.
When the Progressive Conservatives eventually formed a government in 1979, we stuck with the initial principle which we had from the very beginning when lotteries were developed in this country. That was to say, let us get out of the lottery business, let us get out of gaming and gambling. We do not want to be in it. The federal Government has really no right to be in it. An agreement was signed in 1979, with the unanimous consent of the provinces, giving the rights and the jurisdiction of lotteries and gaming to the provinces. Shortly thereafter the Liberal Government was elected, and immediately it went into action, ignoring this duly signed agreement between the provinces and the federal Government, and started to wind its way into the sports pool, directly breaking the agreement that existed between the provinces and the federal Government. That was just another example of the terrible lack of co-operation between the federal Government and the provinces. The rest is history.
The status of the two corporations today, Loto-Canada and the Canadian Sports Pool Corporation, is as follows. Regarding Loto-Canada, on November 1, 1984, some $15.5 million was paid to the Receiver General for Canada and $250,000 was retained to pay outstanding accounts. That was because even after all those years Loto-Canada was still in existence. In fact, the Auditor General said in his report on July 29, 1983, that the lottery was ill-founded by monies that were legally due but not paid to the Receiver General for Canada. He went on to say that he was concerned about the high level of expenses incurred by Loto-Canada. As a result of these inherited irregularities, this Government moved quickly to take the action I just outlined.
With regard to the Canadian Sports Pool Corporation, approval for $36.5 million was obtained on October 26, 1984, by this Government to be allocated in the following manner. Some $20 million was allocated to forgive the start-up loan. The Liberals borrowed $20 million to start up this mess. Then

November 8, 1984
Sports Pool Corporation
another $16.5 million was allowed to pay outstanding accounts which were derived as a result of losses.
I believe, Mr. Speaker, to put an end to this whole thing now, that the remaining matters relating to this corporation will be cleared up in the very near future. It is in very good and capable hands, that of the Minister of National Health and Welfare and officials of the Treasury Board and of the Department of Justice, and I am confident that this will soon be behind us.
To go back to the Olympic commitment and how we are going to raise the necessary funds, that is the number one question. Let me point out, Mr. Speaker, that it was never expected or intended that the full $200 million would be funded entirely from the sports pool profit. The previous Government saw this as only one of several sources of funding, and at least some of those we are actively considering. Others that we have in mind were not, as far as we know, considered by the previous Government.
Now, because the positive spin-off from the games by way of social, economic and cultural benefits will be realized by all provinces and regions of Canada, it is no secret that I have been negotiating and discussing with the provinces not only to engage them in partnership to help fund the Olympics, but also to work together in supporting and improving fitness and sports programs in a more co-ordinated fashion. I have had the opportunity to meet with my provincial counterparts responsible for fitness, sports and recreation, with some of them on numerous occasions now, and I can assure you that a true feeling of federal and provincial co-operation and consultation has become more than evident. I have also met and am continuing to meet with provincial Ministers responsible for lotteries. Of the ten Ministers who are fitness and sports or recreation Ministers, only four are responsible for lotteries. The other six are in different portfolios. I can report that progress is being made in forging the type of partnership between this Government and the provinces that I referred to earlier.
That is one way. There are other ways and means at which we are currently looking to help fund the Calgary Olympics, indeed, to help fund fitness and sports programs in the long run. For example, we will be introducing legislation to create an Olympic coin program, which should generate between $30 million and $50 million, depending on the price of silver and gold at that time. At present, the proposed program would involve 12 issues of one $20 silver coin, with a maximum mintage of six million units, and one issue of one $100 coin, with a maximum mintage of 350,000 units. An agreement for the use of the Olympic marks is currently being negotiated with the Mint, the Canadian Olympic Association and the International Olympic Committee. We are also seriously pursuing increased corporate sponsorship in the area of amateur sports and examining various ways to encourage the corporate sector to become more involved on a long-term basis after the games are held.
I truly believe, Mr. Speaker, that with some effort on our part the private sector can play a far greater role in both the
funding of the Olympics as well as in being more directly involved in assisting fitness and sports programs, not only between now and 1988 but beyond that time. I am very seriously looking into ways and means of coming up with some form of incentives for the private sector to do just that.
I prefaced my address, Mr. Speaker, by emphasizing that this Government will be honouring its commitments to provide financial support for the 1988 Winter Olympic Games in Calgary. Indeed, we take this $200 million commitment very seriously. As I indicated previously, I would like to take this opportunity to expound a little on the allocation of those funds. Perhaps the most important of all the federal monies in the long term is the $30 million for the Olympic Endowment Fund. This is in fact a legacy for our athletes, both present and future Olympians. The fund will be used toward maintenance and operation of the Olympic facilities and will ensure that our national team athletes have world class training centres, such as the speed skating oval and the Olympic Park. In addition, these facilities will draw world class athletes and coaches from all over the world to train in Canada. This is yet another benefit which will stay as a legacy. Most important, these facilities are going to be used by the Canadian people themselves, from minor leaguers and beginners right up to those who are training for international events. So the legacy of the Olympics will live on after 1988. It is with pride that the Canadian people are going to look toward 1988 as the best ever Olympics.
Other funding includes $27.8 million toward the budgeted cost of the Olympic Saddledome; $35 million for the Olympic Oval, which is to be constructed by the University of Calgary; $62.2 million toward the Canada Olympic Park, which includes the ski jumps, the luge and bobsled runs; $30 million towards the Olympic Endowment Fund, to which I just referred; and $45 million toward operating funding for OCO '88, it being the Calgary Olympic Organizing Committee. To date we have expended $48 million of the $200 million commitment. In addition to direct funding, we have promised to provide essential federal services such as security, immigration and customs. The Government of Canada may also provide certain discretionary services on a cost-recovery basis.
Having said all this, Mr. Speaker, we are very proud that we were able to move as quickly as we did in closing down the sports pool in good faith with the provinces, a move which made good economic sense as far as the taxpayers are concerned because of the $1 million to $1.5 million loss per week. 1 can report to you that the funding to replace this $200 million commitment is proceeding on schedule. I can also report to you that the construction projects in Calgary to which I just referred are proceeding according to schedule. Having seen the sites myself and having met the top notch organizers of OCO '88 in Calgary and across the country, I am confident that the Winter Games in Calgary in 1988 are going to be the most successful ever held anywhere in the world and that Canadians will be proud of what we, along with the organizers, are doing and will do between now and then.
November 8, 1984
