speakeroldname: Hon. John A. Fraser (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans) moved
speechtext:
that Bill C-5, an Act to amend the Freshwater Fish Marketing Act, be read the second time and referred to the Standing Committee on Fisheries and Forestry.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I want to commence this afternoon by extending to all of my colleagues from whatever Party who have returned to the House and to those from whatever Party who are here for the first time my congratulations and best wishes for their efforts on behalf of Canadians who elected them to take their place in this Chamber in the coming years. I think it is appropriate to set on the record that while there will always be controversy, dispute and argument in this Chamber, in keeping with the best principles of civility most of us who have been here for any period of time have learned to realize that we treat each other with respect and indeed sometimes even with affection. Therefore, I extend my best wishes to all of my colleagues and my commitment to work with all Members to achieve the task for which the public has sent us here.
Today I have the pleasure to introduce for second reading Bill C-5, which is legislation to increase the committed borrowing limit of the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation to $30 million from the present level of $20 million.
I am extremely hopeful that Hon. Members will see fit to give speedy passage to this piece of legislation which was left over from the previous session, as its implementation is of considerable importance to the effective operation of the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation and the 3,500 fishermen who depend on the corporation for their economic survival.
I should point out that on the previous occasions when it was deemed necessary to increase the borrowing limit, this was accomplished through submissions contained in Supplementary Estimates. However, some Hon. Members may recall that this procedure was challenged in the House and, as a result, the Speaker ruled that the only way to effect a change to the borrowing limit was through an amendment to the Freshwater Fish Marketing Act.
When the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation was first formed in 1969, the borrowing limit was set at $5 million. This ceiling was raised to $10 million in 1970, and to the current level of $20 million in 1974. Needless to say, since 1974
November 8, 1984

market prices along with operating costs, cost of fuel, wages, etc., have risen steadily, and there is now a demonstrated need to adjust the borrowing limit upwards.
It might be useful to Hon. Members if I reviewed briefly the situation which led to the creation of this Crown corporation and explain how it operates.
The Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation was formed mainly at the request of the prairie Provinces at a time when they were very concerned about the recurrent price weaknesses for freshwater fish. It was a time when the fish resources of this area were largely neglected, the fishermen felt abandoned and exploited, and there was no consistency or policy that allowed the fishermen a decent return for their work. With the exception of the Great Lakes, the marketing, processing and export of freshwater fish was traditionally carried out by many small firms. As most of this production was exported to the United States, the small Canadian exporters were usually at a disadvantage when attempting to deal with the large and powerful American importers. This resulted in a wide fluctuation in prices during the season, which in turn created instability and uncertainty among operating firms and the fishermen.
When the Mclvor Royal Commission of Inquiry on freshwater fish marketing looked into the situation existing at that time, it found that the business was made up of some 6,000 fishermen, about 200 packer-dealers and 35 processor-exporters. It had an average total production of freshwater fish of approximately 72 million pounds and an export value of about $17 million. The fishermen are rather sparsely scattered throughout this vast expanse, and the majority of them are native people who have no alternative way of making a living other than fishing. There are several ethnic groups and many language dialects.
The commission found that facilities for receiving, handling, packing and storing the fish catch were not only primitive but generally unsuitable. The processing plants needed in this highly competitive business were almost non-existent.
The commission also found that the fishermen were receiving too small a share for the price paid by the consumer. Because they did not speak as one voice, they were relatively weak as sellers and they bore all the risks and uncertainties encountered in exporting.
The findings of the Mclvor Commission resulted in the creation of the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation on February 27, 1969. The basic philosophy underlying the legislation to establish the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation was, and still is, that returns to freshwater fishermen could best be increased through the establishment of a single selling body with the exclusive right to market and trade in fish in the interprovincial and export trade.
Through the corporation, freshwater fish is now being marketed in an orderly manner, with none of the fluctuations in earnings experienced by fishermen in earlier years. The corporation is also promoting and expanding in international markets, not just in the United States which has been the tradi-
Freshwater Fish Marketing Act tional market, but in European countries as well. Determined efforts are also made to expand our Canadian markets.
The corporation handles virtually all freshwater fish produced in Canada outside the Great Lakes, which amounts to about 50 per cent of Canada's total annual production. The area of operations, covering more than five million square kilometres, includes northwestern Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and the Northwest Territories. In those regions the corporation buys fish either directly from fishermen or through agents, establishes initial prices for fishermen, packages and processes the fish, and markets them at home and abroad. About 90 per cent of all this fish is exported, and most of that goes to the United States.
The corporation, which has its main processing facility in the Winnipeg area, is obliged to operate on a self-sustaining basis. At the beginning of the season it establishes an initial price, which in practice is a floor price for the operating season. Any additional returns from the market are passed on to the fishermen at the end of the season or when the product is sold from inventory.
At this point Hon. Members might be interested in learning something of the current marketing operations of the corporation. I think I can do no better than quote from the latest issue of Freshwater Country, a very informative newsletter issued by the corporation. In his marketing report, Peter Smith, VicePresident of Marketing, said:
At the same time that the coastal fisheries are struggling to survive, there has been a dramatic improvement in our financial position here at the Corporation. Our 1983/84 fiscal year which ended in April was extremely profitable, and we expect a sizeable final payment in December.
During 1982/83 the recession in the United States continued to have negative effects on the fishing industry nationwide. Consumers were short of cash and concerned about the future. As a result, they continued to shop for the least expensive items available, and avoided expenses which they viewed as a luxury. This had a negative effect on sales and especially those to the restaurant trade ... a market which is extremely important to our Freshwater fishery.
While our industry continued to struggle with recessionary forces, production of some of our major species remained at record levels. This was particularly the case with pickerel and the result was a major decrease in prices to fishermen, as inventories climbed to uncomfortable levels.
Production from our major competitors on the Great Lakes was also too high, especially during the winter. In normal years, the Corporation faces light competition in the winter fresh market, but warm weather enabled Great Lakes producers to continue fishing during the winter of 1982/83. As a result, Great Lakes producers captured a large portion of the fresh market, and prices dropped dramatically due to the surplus of fresh fish available.
Other producers of fish from around the world were also attracted to the United States market because of the extremely high value of United States currency. This encouraged countries as distant as New Zealand to start shipping large quantities of fish into United States markets. Orange Roughy was one of these products. These boneless, skinless snow white fillets have been selling to restaurants for as low as $2.20 a pound.
It seemed that absolutely nothing could go right for us during 1982/83 and it was not surprising when the Corporation was only able to show a year end profit of $40,000 on over $39 million in sales.
During 1983/84 things started to turn around for the Corporation. Although we still faced heavy competition from other producers of fish, there was some easing of recessionary forces in our major markets. At the same time, production of pickerel dropped to normal levels in the Freshwater area and whitefish production remained manageable. Winter production on the Great Lakes was

November 8, 1984
Freshwater Fish Marketing Act
also down as a result of freezing weather, and the Corporation experienced a lucrative winter season.
By the end of April, 1984 it was clear that the year had generated a substantial profit. This will be available to fishermen in the form of final payments in December, 1984.
In starting the New Year, we find ourselves in an extremely good inventory situation relative to pickerel and whitefish. Furthermore, we expect that market prices for pickerel will hold up this year, and that prices for whitefish will remain relatively stable, notwithstanding any dramatic increases in production here or on the Great Lakes. This is all reflected in initial prices to fishermen, which show a substantial increase for pickerel and some increases for whitefish as well.
We continue to have concerns about sauger. Harvests of sauger increased by 50 per cent last year, and this inventory will have to be moved in order to affect any increases in the price of this species. The large majority of our sauger is breaded by the food service trade and is sold to family oriented restaurants that serve budget-minded clientelle.
Northern pike is another product that has given us cause for concern. Our major market in France has been unstable for several years as a result of the declining value of French currency. As a result, the price to our French customers has been steadily increasing, while revenues earned by the Corporation have remained unchanged. Last year's decrease in production came at an opportune time since exports to France were down 15 per cent. We hope that pike deliveries will remain moderate this year... especially considering the effect that Swedish pike production is beginning to have on our French market. Pike production from Sweden is expected to be 250,000 kilograms this year and estimates are that it will increase to 500,000 kilograms by 1985. The combined effects of devalued French currency and increased competition have already begun to have an impact on our sales of dressed pike. The switch to headless pike is anything but welcome news, but we have little choice given market conditions.
Lake trout prices are up substantially this year. This is primarily due to reduced trout harvests in the Freshwater area. Availability of trout from the Great Lakes is also a factor. Pollution problems there have reduced the supply of trout to the market, and demand is stronger than it has been for some time. A large degree of caution is necessary in dealing with trout, since any sizeable increase in production will dampen prices in this specialized market.
Prevailing prices for pink salmon also impact on trout markets. Today it is common to find headless and dressed pink salmon selling in Canadian supermarkets for as little as $3.72 per kilogram or $1,693 per pound.
Although these factors have not had a major effect on key markets for Lake Trout, we certainly have to be aware of their possible impact in the years ahead.
In this regard, we have some serious concerns about the long term effect of farm-raised salmon and trout. This is a tremendous growth industry in countries like Norway and Sweden, where fish farmers actually supply the market with custom sized fish. Farm raised trout from Argentina have also begun to effect markets in United States cities like Los Angeles, where they are available in retail stores for as low as $2.18 per kilogram or 99 cents per pound.
In the year ahead we will have to be especially cautious in our dealings in both new and existing markets. The forces at work in our industry are very volatile and there is little doubt that the industry will remain unstable into the foreseeable future.
Levels of production will play an especially important role in the year ahead. This is certainly not the time that we can afford any major increases in deliveries of any species.
We will be striking out in some new directions this year in an attempt to broaden the market for our products. This fall for instance, we are making a major move in the Los Angeles area. We will be introducing vacuum-packed pan ready style whitefish into chain stores in an attempt to capture a portion of the market in this major metropolitan center.
We will also be continuing our campaign to sell Northern Canadian Game Fish into exclusive restaurants throughout the United States and Canada. Reaction to this concept has been very positive so far and we are hoping that our efforts will begin to pay off in the year ahead.
That is the end of the article. I thought it was appropriate for it to be included in Hansard because, in a succinct way, it covers extremely well the activities of the corporation.
I am sure Hon. Members will be interested to know that for the fishing season just ending the corporation has had a very good year, with sales in excess of $44 million. A very substantial final payment to fishermen will be announced shortly. I might also add that initial prices for major species have been increased for the 1984-85 upcoming fishing season. This is an indication that the good times will continue for those engaged in the freshwater fishery.
As I mentioned earlier, the current maximum borrowing limit of the corporation of $20 million was established ten years ago. Since that time operating costs have continued to climb, and it makes sense that that borrowing capacity should be increased. If this does not happen, the corporation is likely to find itself in the impossible position of being obliged under its mandate to buy all the fish offered to it and at the same time will have insufficient credit reverses to be able to pay the fishermen, which, to say the least, would be most unfortunate. With the disposition of Hon. Members, I think that is not a likely outcome.
In conclusion, I would again like to stress the importance of speedy passage of this amended legislation in order that the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation can plan its budget for the upcoming fiscal year and properly carry out the job for which it was created.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to speak today on this Bill, an Act to amend the Freshwater Fish Marketing Act. It is a pleasure because this was placed on the Order Paper on one or two occasions by the previous Government.
Before speaking on the Bill, I would like to offer my congratulations to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans (Mr. Fraser) on his appointment. Like other Members, I wish him well, but not too well. I also congratulate him on bringing this Bill to the floor of the House so quickly. It is rather amusing that the first Bill the Minister brings in has to do with Crown corporations and, of course, in a positive way. I was under the
November 8, 1984

impression from the Minister of Regional Industrial Expansion (Mr. Stevens) that Crown corporations were a sort of bad word. There is a valuable role for Crown corporations to play in our society, and I guess the Minister agrees with that.
The Minister of Fisheries and Oceans must have had a tough time with the Minister of Science and Technology, the Hon. Member for Richmond-South Delta, (Mr. Siddon). I remember a debate in this House on July 10, 1980, on a private Member's motion sponsored by the Hon. Member for Richmond-South Delta for the production of papers. At that time I spoke on the Government side in reply to the Hon. Member's request. What was amusing was that the first part of the Minister's speech today referred almost word for word to the speech that was written for me. It was obviously given to him by the Department. I guess that's the way it works.
In his speech, the Hon. Member for Richmond-South Delta was extremely adamant about the role of the Freshwater fish marketing agency. I wish to quote from page 2726 of the Commons Debates for July 10, 1980. This is what the Hon. Member for Richmond-South Delta thought. This guy is now a Minister in the Cabinet and a colleague of our friend, the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans. On July 10, 1980, he said, talking about the concept of the formation of this corporation, and I quote:
That original concept was recommended by the Mclvor commission in the late sixties and advocated by the Conservative government of Duff Roblin in the province of Manitoba. What that concept of a marketing board has become is, as I said a moment ago, a monopolistic, vertically integrated Crown corporation, like so many of our Crown corporations, which handles the product from the lakeside all the way to the consumer, whether the consumer be in the fish buying markets of New York state or Poland.
Here is what he said, and this is why I congratulate the Minister for bringing the Bill forward so quickly:
I suggest what we have now is a system of monopolistic dominance in the fish marketing industry, in the prairie provinces in particular, which is a far cry from what I understand to be the principle of democratic socialism where free enterprise and the private sector can operate in competition with one another. What we have is virtual communism in all of its forms in the example and illustration of the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation.
This has been quite a conversion. I understand the Hon. Member for Western Arctic (Mr. Nickerson) is going to take part in this debate. I will not quote what he was saying, but we will watch him very closely.
I supported this corporation in 1980. My Government supported it. We went back to why the corporation was set up in the first place. It serves northwestern Ontario, the Provinces of Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta and the Western Arctic. In some of those areas there are small communities and outports with a very small fishing population. It is difficult for fishermen in that situation, if they are small processors to compete in the market-place or to get any kind of return on their product.
At the time this corporation was set up, there were business operators who not only owned the little processing businesses and the marketing aspects of their agency, but who also owned the fishermen's gear. In other words, they owned the fishermen. That was not unique for that part of the country. I
Freshwater Fish Marketing Act remember such operators in the fishing industry in the late 1950s and early 1960s in my province. One in particular not only had the processing business, but owned the fisherman's gear and the fisherman's house. Every year when the fisherman tried to get operating capital, there was another lien toward something. It left nothing for the primary producer, the fisherman.
This corporation was set up to help those primary producers who found it difficult to operate in the normal natural process of business. It is true that some of these businessmen have had some quarrel with this corporation. No doubt in some cases, because of the make-up of the corporation, a businessman would have some concern in certain areas. I know that if I were a businessman, I might have some concerns in certain areas. However, I think, as the Minister said earlier, that this corporation does the best for the most people involved in the industry. That is why we are supporting it.
I would like to see what other aspects of the corporation are beneficial. First, back in the 1960s before the corporation was formed, the small operators had tremendous difficulty competing, especially in the American market. There were a great many small exporters, but in the United States there were very few small importers. They were playing one against the other and keeping the price down. That is the kind of situation one can find oneself in when there are a great many small businesses trying to compete nationally and internationally.
The role of the corporation has been expanded to include Poland and some other countries. As the Minister stated, I think it is a bit of a success story. If I understood him correctly, I was very pleased to hear the Minister say that this year, the corporation expects total sales of $44 million and substantial benefits will go back to the fishermen. That, of course, is the principle of the co-operative movements in other parts of the country. Again, I would refer to my own riding in which there are two exceptionally well managed and well operated co-ops that have been able to do a great deal for the small fishermen. They are given a floor price in the spring and after the season is over and sales are complete, the profits are shared.
I believe that the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation has a very positive impact on the western provinces and on western Ontario. I am extremely pleased to see this legislation before us now because it has been on the books for a long while. This Act was first introduced on April 29, 1983, under the heading of Bill C-149. It was introduced to the House at that time by the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans of the former Liberal Government, Mr. De Bane, and was given first reading. However, because of government House business, the Bill did not go through all stages at that time. It was re-introduced by the Hon. Minister as Bill C-31, and that Bill, of course, received only first reading.
There can be no doubt in my mind that in order to run effectively in today's market-place, the borrowing limit of this corporation must be raised. It has been well over a year now

November 8, 1984
Freshwater Fish Marketing Act
since first attempts were made to increase this limit, and I am glad to see that it is finally coming about.
I know other Members wish to speak on this Bill today. Perhaps it will not go through all stages today. In general, I am sure that we in the Official Opposition will agree with it and we hope that the corporation has a successful year this year and that that success will continue for the corporation and for the some 3,500 fishermen it represents well into the future.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. On behalf of the New Democratic Party, I also wish to congratulate you on your nomination as Acting Speaker of the House. I understand there are several Quebec Members who are Conservatives in name but in fact, are New Democrats. If they want to cross the floor they will be most welcome.

Perhaps I might speak in English now so that you can understand me, Mr. Speaker.
This is my maiden speech as fisheries critic. I am looking at the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans (Mr. Fraser) who is present in the House. I would like to say how pleased I am to be fisheries critic as well as energy critic for our Party. I see that the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources (Miss Carney) is present. Just wait. She will get her turn tomorrow or the next day. We will see what happens in the statement that is to be made tonight.
I might as well be honest with the Minister of Fisheries. I do want to say to him-and I think this will be the last time I say this-that I do indeed regard him with a great deal of affection. Not only is he from Vancouver, not only is he outspoken, not only is he a lawyer and a chartered lawyer at that but he is a fellow Scots Canadian. I think that sews it up.
Hear, hear!

He has also been known to have had some principles in the past. My job will be to make sure that those principles do not get lost within this new Conservative Cabinet and to push him so that some of his principles and views, especially those on helping the West Coast fishermen who are in real need, will get through Cabinet.
While I have all of this personal affection for the Minister, I put him on notice that since I represent a riding that borders on Trout Lake in Vancouver, I will expect that he will get some of his initiatives through Cabinet. If he does not, he will hear from us over here.
Having said that, I had better say something about the Freshwater Fish Marketing Act, an Act on which I am an expert and about which I am pleased to speak. Just in case you do not know, Mr. Speaker, I should tell you that the Act was passed in 1969. This corporation has the sole jurisdiction to process and market fish in the prairie provinces, part of northern Ontario and in the Northwest Territories. It does not
have jurisdiction in most of Ontario and in Quebec because those areas can look after themselves. This corporation deals with freshwater fish in one specific region of the country.
You would be interested to know, Mr. Speaker, that the corporation was set up because the private corporations, contrary to the mythology that we hear from the other side day in and day out, could not really handle and badly mismanaged the freshwater fishery industry in this area of Canada. The private corporations were not acting in the best interests of the fishermen. Is that not a surprise? The Government found that these corporations were mainly American controlled and that they were operating in a dog-eat-dog fashion, not a fish-eat-fish fashion. The fishermen were controlled by these corporations by the initial payments made to them. Start-up fees and so on were required at the beginning of the season, and that was too difficult for the fishermen.
The industry was in very bad shape at the end of the 1960s from the fishermen's point of view. Therefore, there was pressure for the establishment of this Crown corporation, which has been working fairly well. I have some criticisms of the Crown corporation which I will be making in a few moments.
You should be aware, Mr. Speaker, as you undoubtedly are, that the freshwater fishing industry is the second largest industry in northern Saskatchewan. Although sales of freshwater fish pale in comparison with sales of coastal fish, it is nonetheless a significant industry and has a great deal of potential for expansion. The Minister referred to some of this potential in his speech when he referred to new markets and so on.
We have the largest supply of freshwater fish in the world. Of course, we have what is probably the largest supply of energy in the world and the largest supply of forestry and minerals in the world. We are only waiting to have the brains to develop these things the way they should be in order to make us the richest country in the world. Some day we will do that.
There is hope.

There is hope. Well, I do not know about that. We will have to wait and see. There is certainly hope for developing this industry.
The Canadian commercial fishing industry in 1982 landed 1.38 million tonnes, valued at $838 million. After processing, the catch was worth about 1.98 billion dollars. This is an industry which the NDP takes very seriously. We give it a very high priority. In the same year, the freshwater commercial fishing landed 550,000 tonnes, which was worth $62 million. Processed freshwater fish products had a value of $100 million. Although freshwater fishing is a small proportion of the Canadian fishing industry, it is nonetheless significant.
The fishing industry exported $1.62 billion worth of products in 1982, which is approximately 82 per cent of the industry's output. In freshwater fish, we exported about 88 per
November 8, 1984

cent; much of it going to the United States, the European Economic Community, and to the rest of Europe and Japan.
I would like to take this opportunity to thank the European Economic Community which was good enough to invite me this fall to study some of their problems. I studied the fishing industry in Denmark, Greece, and Brussels. I learned something about the European fishing industry. We could learn something from the way in which the Europeans handle their catch. I would like to thank publicly the officials of the European Economic Community for being so patient in dealing with an expert in fisheries such as I was at that point.
The major problem with the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation is that it does not own marketing plants in northern Saskatchewan or northern Manitoba. Fishermen living in those areas must ship their fish south to Winnipeg in order for their fish to be processed. Fishermen must bear the cost of shipping the fish south, and it is fairly prohibitive to them. As a result, a lot of fishermen in northern Saskatchewan are a bit peeved off-if I might put it that way-at the corporation. They actually petitioned the previous Government to opt out of the control of the corporation. I believe that was somewhat of an over-reaction, as I think there can be reforms made in the corporation, and 1 propose to suggest some reforms.
I would say to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans that there is a lot of unemployment, both in northern Manitoba and northern Saskatchewan, which is the result of a lack of fish processing plants in those areas. In Lake Athabasca, for example, no fishing is being done on the Saskatchewan side of the lake. Also, there are complaints by fishermen in northern Saskatchewan that the quotas of fish which they are able to sell to the corporation are too low. This affects them, as they must make up for the extra shipping costs and they must ship more fish than their counterparts down South. Therefore, they want higher quotas.
Improvements are required with respect to the management and the operations of the corporation. For example, it is too centralized. It should expand some of its fish processing plants in the northern areas. One suggestion I would make to the Minister is that the board of directors, or its advisory committee, should travel to the northern areas of the provinces and talk to the fishermen about their problems. It is much easier for the board to go north than for the fishermen to go south. It is also much more intimidating for the fishermen to talk to men in three-piece suits than for the men in three-piece suits to go the other way. I know that it does not look very intimidating down here, but very often when people come from the North they find it difficult to deal with this cultural milieu. Therefore, I would make a pragmatic suggestion that the Minister could talk to the board and that the board should go and talk to the fishermen in the northern areas. Then we will not have, as we had in the last Parliament, the instance in which one of our Members from that area was petitioning, on behalf of the fishermen, to opt out of the corporation.
Fishermen are currently represented on the advisory committee of the corporation, but not on the board of directors.
Freshwater Fish Marketing Act Therefore, they have no real decision-making power in the corporation. I say to the Minister of Fisheries, why not put them on the board of directors?
One of the things of which I was made aware in Europe- not with respect to fisheries, but generally-was a movement toward co-determination. That is a situation in which the workers of a company are on the board of directors. It is done in Germany. It gives workers the feeling that they are participating in some of the decisions which affect their lives. There is a certain limitation to this, and it takes a little while to do it, but it is a coming thing. In this corporation, I would suggest that it would be ideal to have some fishermen on the board of directors.
Another aspect of the problem is the general under-utiliza-tion,of the industry. There are lots of whitefish in Saskatchewan waters, but the corporation is not buying them. The corporation gets all it needs from Winnipeg. Thus, in Saskatchewan there is the unfortunate situation in which white-fish can be bought from Manitoba and not from Saskatchewan, despite the fact that Saskatchewan lakes are full of the stock. Much of the fish which lives in the fresh water is suitable for being dried for export. We could be exporting fish to Africa and other Third World countries. There are plenty of markets abroad for fish. We should not limit ourselves to the needs of our country. The opportunities for export would result in more employment and growth in the industry. I spoke with fisheries officials in Athens, Copenhagen and Bonn about their fishing industries and the possibility of accepting more Canadian fish. There are some possibilities which exist in the EEC. We would have to make some exchanges for fishing grounds and other things in return.
When I was in Denmark, a gentleman informed me that if I wanted to know about cars, I should talk to Mercedes in Germany; if I wanted to know about the wine industry, I should go to France; but if I wanted to know about fish, I should talk to them. It is true. They can land fish which are in the North Sea and the Atlantic, and within 24 hours they are on the table in Paris. Not that I have ever eaten in a restaurant in Paris, but I am sure that the Minister occasionally does. The fact remains that whether a person is eating fish and chips or whether he is eating in a restaurant in Paris, the fish is good, and we could learn much from the way they market and process their fish.
My colleague, the Hon. Member for Churchill (Mr. Murphy), spoke in the House last year on this Bill when the capitalization issue was raised. The Minister now wishes to raise it from 20 million to 30 million. That is acceptable to us.
In summation, I hope that this Crown corporation is not privatized. I believe it has a role. I have pointed out some of the criticisms and difficulties which have been expressed by the fisheries, and I do so in good faith. I am sure the Minister will take these remarks back to the corporation. We would like to see more decentralization and more consultation with the fishermen. If we are to be in this together, we should consider the expansion of markets and the enhancement of enhancing the industry, canning, processing and other things. In that way

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: The Hon. Member for Western Arctic.

Mr. Speaker, I listened with a great deal of interest to the Hon. Member for Egmont (Mr. Henderson) and the Hon. Member for Vancouv-er-Kingsway (Mr. Waddell) who said what a great thing this Crown corporation was, a Crown corporation that has a monopoly on the purchase of fish. They said that there may be a few faults with it here and there and with the management, but the Crown corporation has this monopolistic power and that is what they want. Obviously, Sir, they have never talked to a freshwater fisherman.
It is your Bill!

They would have a much different idea of things if they really knew what the FFMC was doing to the fishermen of freshwater country. I have given the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans (Mr. Fraser) the assurance that I will vote in favour of the Bill which he has presented to us today. I do that, Sir, for two principal reasons. First, I am a good Party supporter and would never think of voting against the Ministers of the present Government. I know they are very competent and are doing their best for Canada. I have great faith in them. The second reason, Sir, is that the Minister has threatened to break my arm if I did not vote for the Bill. However, in return, Sir, I expect from the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans that within a matter of just a few months he will bring into this House, in keeping with the policies of the Progressive Conservative Party, a Bill to amend the FFMC Act further, and the nature of that amendment will be to revoke the monopoly of FFMC in order to allow other entities into the market-place. That, Sir, is they key to getting our northern fishing industry going again.
The Hon. Member for Egmont gave us a brief history of this Bill. He told us that it had been brought in in 1980 and had died on the Order Paper. It was brought in again in 1983 as Bill C-31 and again it died on the Order Paper. I want to tell the Hon. Member why it died on the Order Paper. It is because the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans of that day had no concern with the plight of freshwater fishermen at all. That Bill was always No. 151 in priority on a list of 150 Bills. It was put there and absolutely nothing was done with it. That, Sir, is demonstrative of the difference in attitude between the then Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and the present Minister.
The present Minister of Fisheries and Oceans commands the trust of fishermen throughout the whole of Canada. We have replaced complacency on the part of previous Ministers with action.
I would like to touch briefly on some of the figures involved. If one looks at the last available annual report of the FFMC in 1983, one sees that it had working capital loans of some $13.5
million, which was borrowed from the Government of Canada. It had fixed asset loans of some $4.5 million, again borrowed from the Government of Canada. It had approximately $750,000 in bank indebtedness, which brings its indebtedness to a total of somewhere between $18 million and $19 million. Therefore, until the new Government has the time and opportunity to make the necessary changes and if FFMC is to continue for the time being, it is necessary that we make this authorization for a further increase in borrowing authority. However, at the same time as we do this, Mr. Speaker, we should remember that the interest rate on some of those loans is nearly 16 per cent. The fishermen of the northern provinces, the Territories and parts of Ontario are paying about $500,000 a year in interest payments on those loans. What one has in microcosm is a similar situation as with the national finances of this country. In the national case we have accrued debts of billions of dollars and interest must be paid on it, which is cutting into the revenue. The same thing has happened with FFMC. It has had to borrow continuously more and more money, which puts that extra burden on the fishermen who are obliged to pay and pay the interest on those debts, debts which have been run up in the past.
There were many absolute horror stories in the past with respect to FFMC. There were warehouses full of fish and no sales. There was improper management. There was slack financial control of the corporation and all kinds of funny little practices going on. I remember the unauthorized attachment of rabbinical stamps to fish boxes for the Jewish market. I must admit, Sir, that some improvements have been made. I had the opportunity to visit the Transcona plant last summer and I was pleased to see that certain improvements in the operation have been made. There was certainly a better flowthrough of inventory and better inventory control.
I would like at this time to compliment Mr. Sam Cunnah, who was one of the managers there. He has recently retired. I would like to compliment him in public for the work he has done. Undoubtedly there is still room for improvement in the management practices. Improvements have been made in the central plant in Winnipeg and Transcona. However, there are still severe problems in the satellite plants. The plant at Hay River is an example of a plant which is just not doing its proper job. Furthermore, the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation just cannot get out there and sell fish, which is its mandate. That is what it was set up to do, and it is still not doing a proper job of selling fish and receiving a good return on behalf of the fishermen for the extraordinary effort they put into catching fish. In part, that is the world-wide situation. I understand there are equal problems on the East Coast as on the West Coast. However, I believe there are things which can be done so that we can sell the excellent products of our freshwater lakes and rivers.
There are two questions which should be addressed with respect to FFMC. First, should it continue at all? That, of course, is still under study. The new Government is taking a new look at all the Crown corporations in order to determine which ones should continue and which ones could better be
November 8, 1984

dealt with in alternative ways, by privatization in one way or another. Second, if FFMC is to continue, should it retain the monopoly? I do not want to go into any great detail today on the first question except to give to Hon. Members this analogy. The FFMC has always appeared to me to be something like a lobster trap. One can get into it but it is almost impossible to get out. If the fishermen are asked whether they are any better off now that they have the FFMC than they were before, they will say that, no, they are not any better off. In fact, in the old days they were better off because they could sell their fish. There was always some kind of market in which they could sell their fish. I doubt if any Crown corporation can do as well at fish sales as private enterprise. Private enterprise does not have people just sitting there in some fancy office in Winnipeg hoping the phone is going to ring and someone will order fish. One has to get out there and sell. That is the way private enterprise works and would continue to work if we did not have this monstrosity called the FFMC.
The previous Minister, who has now gone to his just reward among the decaying leather seats of the other place, wanted to extend the Crown corporation monopoly into the Great Lakes. He wanted to put everyone down to the same level of misery. He could not stand the successful operation of homestead fisheries in the Great Lakes operated under private enterprise. He just wanted to spread the misery around.
With respect to the question of monopoly, I will say that this question can be addressed fairly quickly, and I hope it will. The position of the Progressive Conservative Party, which was worked out over a period of time and which was one of the promises we made to fishermen during the election campaign, is that we will revoke the monopoly presently enjoyed by the FFMC. That monopoly will be broken. It will be of benefit to two parties. First and foremost, it will be of benefit to the fishermen. They will be able to shop around and sell their fish to the people who will give them the highest price. They will not be in servitude to a monopolistic Crown corporation any more. Second, it will be fair to the people who wish to engage in the business of buying and selling fish. Would you believe, Mr. Speaker, that if I bought fish for resale, processing or whatever, something I consider to be an honourable undertaking, helpful to the country and everything else, I could go to jail under the Act for two years for buying unauthorized fish from a fisherman? Surely that is an infringement on the liberty of Canadians and should not be allowed to last any longer.
It is called orderly marketing.

The socialists call this orderly marketing. They prevent people from going into honourable employment, helping their fellow man, providing jobs, putting good food on the table. This is what they do not want to see.
Talk to any farmer.

Once FFMC gets out of the monopoly side of the business, it might continue to exist. I rather suspect it
Freshwater Fish Marketing Act would not last too long in competition with private enterprise, but I have no objection to its continuing to exist as long as it does not have a monopoly. Once that happens, the alternative is a private operation as it used to be before. People used to invest in the plant for working capital purposes, to buy fish from the fishermen. They would go down to New York or Chicago and sell their fish at the best price they could. That used to work out pretty well. Alternatively, we could have a co-operative arrangement. Right now fishermen cannot form a co-operative to sell their own fish. Surely my socialist friend would approve of that. Perhaps not, because he does not call that orderly marketing. The socialists do not mind the freedom of fishermen to form a co-operative being removed by this House of Commons. I think that if fishermen want to form a producers' co-op, they should be able to do so, but at present they cannot.
There could be provincial involvement. Provinces are already involved. We were told that FFMC is now making a profit, but that is only because of provincial and territorial subsidies to the industry. I know that the Government of the Northwest Territories is putting about $400,000 a year in subsidies into the industry. Some is for price support and some is to help support the packer who goes around the lake to pick up the fish from the lake stations. Even so, the price paid for fish is ridiculously low. What most of the fishermen end up doing is wearing out their nets for nothing. I have a few headlines from local papers: "Fishermen Feeling Financial Crunch". "Fish Prices Still Low". "Bleak Season for N.W.T. Fishermen". So it goes, on and on. I do not think that that will improve until fishermen have the option to sell fish to whomever they want.
For a lower price.
I do not think the taxpayer should have to shoulder this burden.
What about the $10 million?

We have the situation where the nature of the resource is such that it can be exploited profitably. Why can we not do that? Why do Canadian taxpayers have to put money into something which could be operated efficiently with a proper return to the fishermen? In the Territories that resource is one of the best in the world. We are capable of producing premium quality products which ought to be sold for premium prices. This is just not the case because it is mixed in with the other product from the provinces which is not so high in quality. Were the Territories able to develop their own specialty markets, we could command those premium prices. I am sure that in all probability the provinces would be better off too, because they could concentrate on what is then available to them. I know of cases where people have gone out and developed a market, especially for the Arctic char. They have found buyers, told the FFMC about the buyer and asked FFMC to buy fish from them. They wait around for two months and then ask the corporation, "Well, why have we not got an order for this fish?" The FFMC has turned around and

given someone else that order. That is the type of thing that is going on.
My colleague, the newly elected Hon. Member for Nunat-siaq (Mr. Suluk), wanted me to bring to the attention of the House his suggestion that Arctic char should be exempted from the species presently dealt with by FFMC. In the eastern Arctic there is a considerable problem in having to sell through FFMC. It would be relatively easy to go out and find markets for Arctic char. There is not that much produced and it should command fantastic prices. However, with FFMC involved, there is not enough effort put into marketing Arctic char and the producers are just not able to get the prices they would be able to if there was a free market in fish.
I was asked, Sir, to get through some of my remarks as quickly as possible in order that this Bill might get through the House this afternoon, so I will not go through some of the things I had hoped to say respecting the Department of Fisheries and Oceans. Most of it was good. I was going to be very complimentary to the Minister, but I can do that another time. I would perhaps reiterate one of the points he made concerning the need for aqua-culture. If we continue to hunt fish instead of farm fish, we are going to lose out in the markets of the future. It is absolutely essential that the Department of Fisheries and Oceans, through organizations such as the Freshwater Institute, get into research on fish farming so that when in the future other countries have products from their fish farms at lower prices, we will be able to compete with them.
Those, Sir, are my comments on the Bill we have before us. I support the increase in the debt limit at the present time, mainly because we have no other option. The thing has been run into the ground for so long. However, my main pitch has been and will continue to be, until this is implemented in law, that the monopoly of the FFMC should be revoked. Other organizations and entities, whether private enterprise, fishermen's co-op or something brought together by the province or Territory, can also get into that business and Fishermen can continue to enjoy the standard of living they had before this socialistic measure was imposed on them in the late 1960s. We can then get this industry flourishing again. I am sure, with the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans (Mr. Fraser) that we now have, that will happen in the very near future.

Member for Vancouver Kingsway (Mr. Waddell), that there are improvements that can be made to the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation.
I happen to believe that the Minister was speaking along the same lines. I presume the previous speaker for the Conservative Party was speaking for himself. He did not seem to be speaking for the Government. I certainly hope he was not speaking for the Government, because, if it is trying to destroy and dismantle the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation, it is going to be hearing from every fisherman in northern Manitoba and northern Saskatchewan and other parts of the country. They believe that the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation is the best vehicle for protecting their interests.
It is important that all of us realize that it was the failure of private enterprise which created the need for the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation. Most of the fishermen we are talking about are native people. Most of those people have felt that they were being robbed under the old system. They want the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation but they also want reforms brought to it. They want to see more processing taking place in their home communities. They want to see more control of that corporation by the fishermen. They want those types of reforms. They want more information in terms of the actual books of that corporation. That is the type of reform they want and that is a reasonable approach.
One of my complaints about the previous Government is that it never really considered the question of how to reform the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation. It sat back and gave it money. The only debate we ever had in the House was over money, just as we are having at the present time. The debate is with regard to money rather than the actual structural purposes and levels of responsibility for the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation. Those are the types of reforms I would like to see. I hope that when the Government and the new Minister have a chance, that is what we will see.

November 8, 1984
Economic Statement

maintopic: SITTING RESUMED The House resumed at 6.30 p.m.
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I asked my colleagues if they would sit down in order that they did not waste their energy now, in the hope that they might do that after as well as before.
Less than two months ago, this Government came to power with a national mandate for change. We did so because on September 4 the Canadian people made a clear and confident judgment about the future of this country.
Canadians voted for change, and for a better future, because they knew that as a country we could do much more to create that future; to create new growth, jobs and opportunities for all Canadians. In doing so, they have opened the way for a fresh start, for new confidence and a new national consensus toward achieving the promise and potential of Canada.
They voted not only for a change in policies, they voted for a change in the approach of government to the making of those policies. That is our mandate. That is our challenge.

The mandate of September 4 reflects as well a sombre judgment about the recent past. When Canadians looked back, they saw an unprecedented decade of soaring government deficits and rising unemployment; of expansive, intrusive government and sluggish, uncertain economic growth. They saw an economic world that had changed and a country that had not kept pace with that change. They saw their government and their economy dangerously off course and off balance.
Few Canadians will say that things are better today than they were in that great year of hope and achievement, our centennial year. Yet, fewer still believe that we can turn back the clock and return to the "good old days". There are new realities, new challenges. But something fundamental has not changed: our country is still blessed with rich natural resources, with the technological and financial capacity and, above all, the people to fulfill its great promise. It is not time to reclaim that future for all Canadians.
Toward that goal, we have taken stock in these past two months. I want to thank my colleagues for their help in charting our course during this challenging first stage of our mandate. Tonight I will share with Canadians the results of our intensive period of activity so that together we can plan our direction for the next four years.
There has been no holiday from decision-making for this government during this period. We have moved quickly to deal with the urgent need for action on a wide front. A number of decisions have already been announced. Tonight I will be announcing further important measures which make a good start on fulfilling our promises.
But most importantly, I wish clearly to set out the direction which we, as a new government, propose to take to fulfil our mandate for change. And I want to begin the national process of discussion and consultation that is so essential to achieving our goals. I will, therefore, be tabling a paper called "A New Direction for Canada: An Agenda for Economic Renewal". This Agenda paper is a statement of national purpose. It will
be the focus for consultations with all parts of the Canadian community.

The Agenda paper recognizes the important economic responsibilities of provincial governments. Our aim is to promote economic growth in concert with the provinces. Dialogue will take the place of confrontation.
Canadians know that this country has been missing opportunities to create new growth and jobs. They know that our competitive position has eroded; incomes have barely kept pace with inflation; confidence in the future has seeped away; and they have seen that the efforts of government to solve problems have too often made things worse instead of better.
For too long, the Government of Canada has responded to serious problems in our economy by dealing with the symptoms of those problems and ignoring the causes. For too long, government has tried to substitute the judgments of politicians and regulators for the judgments of those in the market place, through excessive regulation and by trying to buy its way, with borrowed money, out of each new problem that arises. We have suffered, for too long, from the growing gap between the rhetoric of reliance on the private sector and the reality of increasing government intervention.
The Government has all too often acted to delay change by protecting, at the taxpayer's expenses, those enterprises which have been too slow to increase their productivity or unable to seize new market opportunities. By being a captive of the past, we have risked forfeiting the future.
As a result, business-and especially small business-has been hamstrung by increasing regulation which has sapped the creative energy necessary to take risks, improve productivity and create permanent and satisfying jobs.
Our objective is to release the creative energies of Canadians to build a better future for themselves, to give young people a chance to make a productive contribution and to open up new opportunities for women in the work place and for older workers who have lost their jobs. We want to put Canada back to work.

maintopic: SITTING RESUMED The House resumed at 6.30 p.m.
speechtext: Hear, hear!

maintopic: SITTING RESUMED The House resumed at 6.30 p.m.
speechtext:
Indeed, our nation's elderly and disabled cannot feel economically secure while so many of our youth are unemployed and the prospects for our economy are so uncertain.
Economic renewal will not come quickly or easily. It will come step by step. This government has resisted politically-appealing "quick-fix" prescriptions. There are no easy solutions for problems which have built up over a decade. Nor will economic renewal come without the co-operation of governments, business, workers and union leaders and other Canadians. Step by step, we must begin to direct our combined efforts
November 8, 1984

toward expansion of the economic pie and away from an increasingly divisive struggle for a share of a static or declining one. We will not only have to work hard, we will have to work together in a truly national effort of economic reconstruction.
This government is prepared to lead this process of economic renewal. We have set for ourselves four challenges:
first, to put our own fiscal house in order so that we can limit, and ultimately reverse, the massive build-up in public debt and the damaging impact this has on confidence and growth;
second, to redefine the role of government so that it provides a better framework for growth and job creation and less of an obstacle to change and innovation;
third, to foster higher investment, greater innovation, increased international competitiveness and a positive climate for the birth and growth of new enterprise; and
fourth, to bring about these changes in a way that is fair, open and consistent with the basic sense of compassion, tolerance and justice that is characteristic of Canadian society. [Translation]
We will not weaken the basic income support programs. Indeed we will seek to find room, within our own capacity and through stronger economic performance, to provide even greater assistance to those Canadians who truly need it.

We have clearly set out in the Agenda paper the direction we believe the country should take, but we had another choice. We could have made more decisions and taken more action now, but to do so in the absence of full consultations would undermine not only the spirit of this undertaking but its effectiveness. We want to discuss further the means of achieving these goals with other governments, labour, business and other Canadians. We want their advice and their co-operation.
These consultations will be critical in determining the specific measures we will take and the timing of these actions. But however difficult the decisions will be, let me be very clear: we are determined to act. I intend to return to this House with my first budget in the spring to lay out the next phase of our program for econoic renewal.
Let me now turn, Mr. Speaker, to the economic and fiscal situation which confronts us.
Our economic legacy is one of high unemployment, inadequate investment, eroded confidence and personal hardship. From mid-1981 to the end of 1982 we suffered through the worst recession since World War II. The recovery, which began in 1983, has been only moderate by post-war standards and has been distinctly weaker than the recovery in the United States. After almost two years of recovery, business and consumer confidence remains weak. Cautious households, facing uncertain employment prospects and little real income growth, continue to save at high rates. Businesses, facing excess capacity, high interest rates and uncertain future prospects, have been reluctant to invest and to hire. Investment is
Economic Statement
more than 20 per cent lower than it was prior to the recession and employment has barely recovered to pre-recession levels.
We are talking here not just of economic failure, but of human tragedy; of real economic hardship suffered by thousands of families; of the social and emotional suffering caused by the loss of a job; and of the loss of hope and self-esteem of young people who find themselves unable to make a productive contribution to society after spending so many years at school. This is the unacceptable price of the failure to provide adequate employment growth.
No less serious or troublesome than the economic legacy is the deficit and accumulated debt situation which we have inherited.
In each of the past ten years the expenditures of the federal government have exceeded its revenues. These continuing deficts have led to an enormous growth in the burden of debt and the costs' of interest on that debt. Moreover, unless we begin now to put our fiscal house in order, that burden of debt will continue to mount rapidly in the future. We are on a very dangerous treadmill.
To underline the seriousness of the situation, let me briefly review our economic and fiscal prospects. They are based on the assumption of slower U.S. growth in 1985, a significant decline in U.S. interest rates after 1985 and reasonably healthy world economic growth from 1986 to the end of the decade.
Based on these assumptions, growth in Canada would likely decline from about 4.2 per cent in 1984 to about 2.4 per cent in 1985. Over the second half of the decade, growth would increase and average about 3.4 per cent per year. While inflation would stay at or below 4 per cent for the remainder of the decade, unemployment would remain unacceptably high- 11 per cent through 1985 and then declining gradually to about 7 per cent by 1990.
With this set of projections and no policy changes, the deficit for this fiscal year would be $34.5 billion, almost $5 billion higher than projected last February by the previous government. That is bad enough but that is not the worst of it. Current projections show the deficit increasing next year to more than $37 billion and remaining between $34 and $38 billion in every year for the balance of this decade. This is in marked contrast to previous projections that showed the deficit declining over that period.
Next year's deficit, at $37.1 billion, would be more than $9 billion higher than projected last February. And this increase would have been even greater if the previous government had not budgeted for a decline in support for direct job creation and training from $2.2 billion this year to only $1.2 billion next year. The increase in the deficit this year and next and its failure to come down in this decade, even with continuing growth, are major reasons for concern.

November 8, 1984
Economic Statement
This is what we inherited. Not only is the situation serious today. If we don't take action it will be even more serious by 1990.
In our centennial year the net federal debt was $18 billion; by the end of this fiscal year it will be about ten times higher, $190 billion; by 1990, if there are no changes, it could approach $410 billion. Let me put this in more personal terms. In 1967 this debt represented about $4,000 per family; this year it represents about $24,000 per family. And by 1990, if we do not take action, it will be the equivalent of about $54,000 for every Canadian family.
I know that economists will tell me that this is not a perfect analogy, but I want to express the problem in its simplest terms. Many of us have taken on heavy debts in the form of a mortgage or a personal loan at some time in our lives. But we have done so because we believed our future incomes would increase faster than the costs of carrying that debt. If our debts and our interest payments continue, year after year, to grow faster than our incomes, we know we have a problem. If we reach the point where we must start borrowing money just to pay the interest on our debts, we know we have a serious problem. But this is the situation in which the Government of Canada finds itself today. This year almost 50 per cent of government borrowing is required just to cover interest costs and, if we do not take action, this will rise to more than 76 per cent by 1990. We believe we must act now to avoid a future crisis.

There is no easy solution to the problem we face. We cannot just grow our way out of it. Next year we will have completed the third year in this economic recovery and in each of those years the deficit will have increased-from $25 billion in 1982-83 to $31.8 billion last year, to $34.5 billion this year to a projected $37.1 billion next year.

Moreover, the economic and deficit projections I have given-distressing as they are-are based on an assumption that interest rates will fall to more normal levels in the second half of the 1980s. This assumption follows from my expectation that the returning United States administration and the new Congress will act to reduce the U.S. budgetary deficit and that this will allow the achievement of lower interest rates.
I would be the first to acknowledge that there can be no guarantee that this will be the case. And if interest rates do not fall, our economic and fiscal situation would be even worse. Growth would be lower and the unemployment rate could remain above 10 per cent for the balance of this decade. The federal deficit would continue to increase and could reach $50 billion per year by the early 1990s.
Finally, let me make it perfectly clear that the deficit projections I am presenting tonight are calculated on the same basis as those of the previous government, with one exception. For a number of years, the Auditor General has rightly argued that the accounting policies of the previous government did not give this House or Canadians an accurate presentation of the
government's Financial position. In order to provide a clear picture of the country's finances. I am announcing tonight that the government is prepared to implement most of the suggestions made by the Auditor General.

speechtext:
These changes result in an increase in the projected deficit for this and subsequent years by amounts ranging from $500-$800 million annually. Full details are set out in the Agenda paper.

The projections for economic growth, unemployment and the deficit which I have presented are unacceptable. We can do better, but only if we approach this major challenge in a realistic way. And that means facing up to the deficit and debt outlook I have just described. The simple fact is that the mounting federal debt has become a powerful obstacle to growth and to private sector job creation.

A continuously rising ratio of debt to income threatens growth in three ways. It puts upward pressure on interest rates by raising expectations of future inflation and by competing for private savings. It limits the Government's ability to meet priority economic and social needs. And it symbolizes a state of economic mismanagement that undermines confidence and threatens the job-creating private investment that Canada dearly needs.
To promote growth and jobs, interest rates must be as low as can reasonably be attained. Confidence must be restored. That is why we must take action to limit the deficit. We must assure savers and investors, in Canada and abroad, that the impressive gains we have made on inflation will be consolidated and continued and that the federal government will not place undue demands on Canadian capital markets. Such assurances can be provided only by responsible monetary and fiscal policies. Monetary policy must continue to stand firm against inflationary pressures. Fiscal policy must ease the burden on monetary policy and contribute directly to increased confidence and to lower interest rates.
This government is committed to act now. Because I believe that deficit reduction is the key to rebuilding confidence, and confidence is the key to growth and job creation, controlling the deficit must be our priority for this year and for each year of our mandate. The goals of deficit control and increasing job opportunities cannot be separated.

maintopic: SITTING RESUMED The House resumed at 6.30 p.m.
speechtext: Hear, hear!

maintopic: SITTING RESUMED The House resumed at 6.30 p.m.
speechtext:
For us the question is not whether to act or when to act, but how best to act.
We believe that there are things government should do more of in this country to promote growth, jobs and social justice. We set out earlier this year a number of policy initiatives and I will announce action on some of these tonight. But, as the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) said during the summer, we
November 8, 1984

are committed to implement these policies within an over-all framework of fiscal responsibility over the course of our mandate. And this means that to do more in some areas, we must do less in others.

Our immediate goal is to reduce the deficit through expenditure reductions and not through major tax increases. We have begun a searching examination of our own operations and of government programs. My colleague, the President of the Treasury Board, has directed an assessment of expenditure reductions and revenue recovery measures that can be implemented immediately, in order to begin to reduce the deficit and to create room for us to take new initiatives. He has had the full and complete co-operation of all ministers.
As a result of this review, I am able to announce that more than $4.2 billion of expenditure reductions and revenue recovery measures will be implemented in 1985-86.

maintopic: SITTING RESUMED The House resumed at 6.30 p.m.
speechtext: Hear, hear!

maintopic: SITTING RESUMED The House resumed at 6.30 p.m.
speechtext:
That is the first full year of our mandate and the first opportunity that we have to make a meaningful cut in the size of the federal Government spending. These measures, though, will have a continuing impact. On behalf of my colleague, the President of the Treasury Board (Mr. de Cotret), I will be tabling the full details of these measures later this evening.
In developing these measures, we have made every effort to look first and look hard at our own operations. About $700 million of the total expenditure reductions I am announcing tonight comes from overhead reductions and general restraint measures.
At a time when Canadians are being asked to accept reductions in government programs and services, it is appropriate that Cabinet and Parliament also contribute.
Ministerial pay of the Prime Minister and Cabinet members will be reduced by 15 per cent and 10 per cent respectively for the year beginning January 1, 1985.
Parliament will be asked to reduce its expenditures. The government will ask the appropriate authorities in both Houses of Parliament to examine the expenditures of Parliament as thoroughly as we have examined the expenditures of government, including greater cost-recovery in the operations of the parliamentary restaurant.
